items.title: Nursing unions call for UK to back prosecutions for war crimes against health workers
items.standfirst: Calls come as report shows number of health workers killed in conflicts has risen five-fold in less than a decadeWar crimes targeting health workers, patients and facilities should be prioritised for international criminal prosecution, senior nursing and medical leaders have urged.The number of health workers killed annually in conflicts has jumped five-fold in less than a decade, and the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) and British Medical Association (BMA) have called for action from the UK government to fully back international criminal court (ICC) prosecutions of perpetrators. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: ‘You are constantly told you are evil’: inside the lives of diagnosed narcissists
clusters.neutral_headline: Inside the Lives of Diagnosed Narcissists

items.title: ‘You are constantly told you are evil’: inside the lives of diagnosed narcissists
items.standfirst: Few psychiatric conditions are as stigmatised or as misunderstood as narcissistic personality disorder. Here’s how it can damage careers and relationships – even before prejudice takes its tollThere are times when Jay Spring believes he is “the greatest person on planet Earth”. The 22-year-old from Los Angeles is a diagnosed narcissist, and in his most grandiose moments, “it can get really delusional”, he says. “You are on cloud nine and you’re like, ‘Everyone’s going to know that I’m better than them … I’ll do great things for the world’.”For Spring, these periods of self-aggrandisement are generally followed by a “crash”, when he feels emotional and embarrassed by his behaviour, and is particularly vulnerable to criticism from others. He came to suspect that he may have narcissistic personality disorder (NPD) after researching his symptoms online – and was eventually diagnosed by a professional. But he doesn’t think he would have accepted the diagnosis had he not already come to the conclusion on his own. “If you try to tell somebody that they have this disorder, they’ll probably deny it,” he says – especially if they experience feelings of superiority, as he does. “They’re in a delusional world that they made for themselves. And that world is like, I’m the greatest and nobody can question me.” Continue reading...
items.content: Few psychiatric conditions are as stigmatised or as misunderstood as narcissistic personality disorder. Here’s how it can damage careers and relationships – even before prejudice takes its tollThere are times when Jay Spring believes he is “the greatest person on planet Earth”. The 22-year-old from Los Angeles is a diagnosed narcissist, and in his most grandiose moments, “it can get really delusional”, he says. “You are on cloud nine and you’re like, ‘Everyone’s going to know that I’m better than them … I’ll do great things for the world’.”For Spring, these periods of self-aggrandisement are generally followed by a “crash”, when he feels emotional and embarrassed by his behaviour, and is particularly vulnerable to criticism from others. He came to suspect that he may have narcissistic personality disorder (NPD) after researching his symptoms online – and was eventually diagnosed by a professional. But he doesn’t think he would have accepted the diagnosis had he not already come to the conclusion on his own. “If you try to tell somebody that they have this disorder, they’ll probably deny it,” he says – especially if they experience feelings of superiority, as he does. “They’re in a delusional world that they made for themselves. And that world is like, I’m the greatest and nobody can question me.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Jay Spring, a diagnosed narcissist, experiences grandiose moments.
These moments are often followed by feelings of embarrassment and vulnerability.
He suspected he had narcissistic personality disorder after online research.
He was diagnosed by a professional after self-assessment.
He believes people with the disorder often deny the diagnosis.

clusters.title: Late-night pub openings aren’t in the right spirit | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Late-Night Pub Openings Not in the Right Spirit, Letters Say

items.title: Late-night pub openings aren’t in the right spirit | Letters
items.standfirst: Readers respond to government plans for extending pub hours, highlighting the financial and health costs The government’s plan to extend licensing hours seems to be a rather desperate measure to encourage growth (Pubs to stay open until early hours in push for UK growth, 8 October). Will there be enough customers for pubs to afford the additional staffing and running costs of staying open later?Many pubs are already closing early on some evenings and perhaps not opening on others. If the government really wants to give licensed premises a boost, it should find a way of reducing the price of the drinks they sell, but this would be unpalatable when it’s looking for ways to raise taxes. Continue reading...
items.content: Readers respond to government plans for extending pub hours, highlighting the financial and health costs The government’s plan to extend licensing hours seems to be a rather desperate measure to encourage growth (Pubs to stay open until early hours in push for UK growth, 8 October). Will there be enough customers for pubs to afford the additional staffing and running costs of staying open later?Many pubs are already closing early on some evenings and perhaps not opening on others. If the government really wants to give licensed premises a boost, it should find a way of reducing the price of the drinks they sell, but this would be unpalatable when it’s looking for ways to raise taxes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Readers responded to government plans for extended pub hours.
The letters highlight financial and health costs of the plan.
Some pubs already close early or do not open at all.
The government wants to encourage growth by extending hours.
Readers suggest reducing drink prices instead of extending hours.

items.title: What is the best pillow for your sleeping style?
items.standfirst: The wrong pillow can disrupt sleep, so finding the right one can guard against decline in mental and physical healthI thought I found the perfect pillow. Could these three unseat my favorite?Life is full of mysteries: What is dark matter? What happened to DB Cooper? And the most perplexing to me personally: how tall should pillows be?I can never seem to find the right pillow. They always seem too soft and flat, or too tall and stiff, and I end up tossing and turning all night. Currently, there are six pillows on my bed, none of which are quite right. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Dementia risk for people who quit smoking in middle age ‘same as someone who never smoked’
clusters.neutral_headline: Dementia risk for people who quit smoking in middle age ‘same as someone who never smoked’

items.title: Dementia risk for people who quit smoking in middle age ‘same as someone who never smoked’
items.standfirst: Research finds kicking the habit halves rate of decline in verbal fluency and slows memory loss by 20%People who stop smoking in middle age can reduce their cognitive decline so dramatically that within 10 years their chances of developing dementia are the same as someone who has never smoked, research has found.Kicking the habit halves the rate of decline in verbal fluency and slows the loss of memory by 20%, according to a study of 9,436 people in England, the US and 10 other European countries. Continue reading...
items.content: Research finds kicking the habit halves rate of decline in verbal fluency and slows memory loss by 20%People who stop smoking in middle age can reduce their cognitive decline so dramatically that within 10 years their chances of developing dementia are the same as someone who has never smoked, research has found.Kicking the habit halves the rate of decline in verbal fluency and slows the loss of memory by 20%, according to a study of 9,436 people in England, the US and 10 other European countries. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Quitting smoking in middle age halves the rate of decline in verbal fluency.
It also slows memory loss by 20% in those who quit smoking.
Research studied 9,436 people in England, the US, and other European countries.
Within ten years, former smokers' dementia risk equals non-smokers'.
The study highlights the cognitive benefits of quitting smoking.
